question:
The Jain temple at Pattadakal was built by ___________ .

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
The Jain temple at Pattadakal, also known as the Jain Narayana Temple, was constructed in the 9th century CE. Unlike the other nine temples at Pattadakal, which were built by the Chalukyas and are predominantly Hindu, the Jain temple was built under the patronage of the Rashtrakuta dynasty, possibly during the reign of King Krishna II.This temple stands out for its plainer ornamentation compared to the richly decorated Chalukyan temples and houses an image of a Jina (Jain Tirthankara) rather than Hindu deities.

The Rashtrakutas were successors to the Chalukyas in the Deccan region after the fall of the Chalukyan empire. Their sponsorship of the Jain temple reflects the religious diversity and tolerance of the period. Archaeological evidence, including excavations by the Archaeological Survey of India, confirms the Rashtrakuta contribution to the temple's construction and the presence of a significant Jain community in the region during their rule.

Extra Information:

  • The Jain Narayana Temple is built in the Dravidian architectural style and features a square sanctum, a circumambulatory path, an antechamber, a mantapa (hall), and a porch.
  • The temple’s mantapa is divided into seven bays, with niches containing seated Jinas, and the structure includes lathe-turned sandstone pillars and decorative carvings.
  • The Chalukyas built the other major Hindu temples at Pattadakal, but the 10th Jain temple was distinctly a Rashtrakuta contribution.

question:
Who was the last tirthankara of the Jainas?

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
Vardhamana Mahavira was the 24th and last Tirthankara of Jainism in the present cosmic cycle (Avasarpini).He lived in the 6th century BCE and is a historical figure whose existence and teachings are well documented. Mahavira succeeded Parshvanatha, the 23rd Tirthankara, and played a pivotal role in shaping Jain doctrine and community life. His teachings emphasized the principles of non-violence (Ahimsa), truthfulness (Satya), non-stealing (Asteya), chastity (Brahmacharya), and non-possession (Aparigraha).

Mahavira’s spiritual leadership and reforms led to the widespread growth of Jainism, and his followers are known as Jains. The teachings of Mahavira form the core of Jain philosophy and are preserved in Jain scriptures. The other options—Chandraprabha, Rishabhanatha, and Padmaprabha—were earlier Tirthankaras, with Rishabhanatha being the first.

Extra Information:

  • Mahavira attained Kevala Jnana (omniscience) after 12 years of intense asceticism.
  • He attained moksha (liberation) at Pawapuri, Bihar.
  • Jain tradition holds that there are 24 Tirthankaras in each half of the cosmic cycle, with Mahavira as the last in the current cycle.

question:
At the age of _________ Mahavira left home and went to live in a forest.

SSC MTS 21/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
Vardhamana Mahavira, the 24th and last Tirthankara of Jainism, was born into a royal family in Kundagrama (near Vaishali in present-day Bihar). At the age of 30, Mahavira renounced his home, family, and royal comforts to become an ascetic and seek spiritual truth. He spent the next 12 years practicing intense meditation and severe austerities in forests and villages, ultimately attaining Kevala Jnana (omniscience).

This act of renunciation at the age of 30 is a significant event in Jain tradition, symbolizing the pursuit of spiritual liberation over worldly attachments. After attaining enlightenment, Mahavira spent the rest of his life teaching the principles of Jainism, such as non-violence, truth, and non-possession.

Extra Information:

  • Mahavira’s renunciation is called “Mahabhinishkramana” in Jain texts.
  • He attained Kevala Jnana at the age of 42 and preached for about 30 years.
  • Mahavira’s life and teachings are foundational to Jain philosophy and ethics.

question:
Where did Lord Mahavira attain salvation?

SSC MTS 13/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
Lord Mahavira, the 24th and last Tirthankara of Jainism, attained salvation (nirvana or moksha) at Pawapuri, which is located in the Nalanda district of Bihar. According to historical and Jain texts, Mahavira achieved nirvana in 528 BCE at this sacred site.After his death, he was cremated at Pawapuri, and the place became a major pilgrimage center for Jains.

The famous Jal Mandir (Water Temple) at Pawapuri marks the spot where Mahavira was cremated and is revered as the place of his nirvana.The temple is built in the middle of a lotus-filled pond, and it is said that so many followers took soil from the cremation site that a large pond was created, which was later filled with water and the temple constructed within it.Pawapuri is also called "Apapuri," meaning "the town without sins," and is one of the holiest sites in Jainism.

Extra Information:

  • Every year, especially on Kartik Amavasya (the day of Mahavira’s nirvana), thousands of Jain devotees visit Pawapuri to pay homage.
  • The Jal Mandir at Pawapuri is an architectural marvel and a symbol of peace and spiritual liberation.
  • Mahavira’s teachings and his attainment of moksha at Pawapuri are central to Jain religious tradition and pilgrimage.

question:
Name the holy city recognized as the birthplace of the first and fourth Jain Tirthankaras.

SSC CHSL 26/10/2020 (Morning)
solution:
Ayodhya isrecognized asthe holy citythat is the birthplaceof both the firstand fourth JainTirthankaras. Accordingto Jain traditionand historicalsources, LordRishabhanatha (also calledAdinath), thefirst Tirthankara, andLord Abhinandananatha, thefourth Tirthankara, wereboth born inAyodhya.

Infact, Jain textsstate that atotal of fiveTirthankaras—Rishabhanatha(1st), Ajitanatha (2nd), Abhinandananatha (4th), Sumatinatha (5th), andAnantanatha (14th)—were bornin Ayodhya.Thismakes Ayodhya asignificant pilgrimagecenter for theJain community, alongside itsimportance inHindu tradition. The city ishome to severalJain templesand is reveredfor its spiritualheritage andconnection tothe lives ofthese Tirthankaras.

ExtraInformation:

  • Rishabhanatha isconsidered thefounder of Jainism and is alsomentioned inHindu texts.
  • Ayodhya is not onlya major centerfor Jain pilgrimsbut also a siteof great historicaland culturalimportance inIndia.
  • Thecity’s associationwith multipleTirthankaras highlightsits spiritualsignificancein Jain tradition.

question:
According to Jain Philosophy, the term ‘Jina’ means __________ .

SSC CGL 07/03/2020 (Evening)
solution:
According to Jain philosophy, the term ‘Jina’ literally means “the conqueror”.In Jainism, a Jina is one who has conquered inner passions such as attachment, aversion, pleasure, pain, love, and hate, and has thereby freed the soul from the bondage of karma and the cycle of rebirth.

Jinas are not conquerors in the worldly sense, but are spiritual victors who have attained liberation (moksha) through self-discipline, renunciation, and right knowledge.The followers of Jainism are called Jains, meaning “followers of the Jina.” The Jinas are revered as Tirthankaras, spiritual teachers who show the path to liberation for others.

The word “Jina” encapsulates the essence of Jain spiritual achievement—victory over the self and all material and emotional fetters.

Extra Information:

  • The term ‘Jina’ is the root for the word “Jain.”
  • Jinas are considered omniscient beings who have achieved perfect knowledge (Kevala Jnana) and eternal bliss.
  • There have been 24 Tirthankaras (Jinas) in the current time cycle, with Mahavira being the last.
  • The code of conduct for Jains—Ahimsa (non-violence), Satya (truth), Asteya (non-stealing), Aparigraha (non-possession), and Brahmacharya (chastity)—is based on the teachings of the Jinas.

question:
The Shailendra kings who founded their empire in South-east Asia in the 8th Century AD were the followers of __________ .

SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
The Shailendra kings, who established their empire in Southeast Asia in the 8th century AD, were renowned followers and patrons of Mahayana Buddhism. Their rule was centered in Java and extended to parts of Sumatra, Bali, and the Malay Peninsula. The Shailendra dynasty is best known for its monumental Buddhist architecture, most notably the construction of the Borobudur temple in Central Java, which remains the largest Buddhist monument in the world.

Historical records, inscriptions, and archaeological evidence consistently point to the Shailendras’ deep devotion to Buddhism, especially the Mahayana tradition. While Shaivism, Jainism, and Hinduism were also present in the region, the Shailendra kings’ most significant cultural and religious contributions were to Buddhism, as reflected in their temple-building activities and support for Buddhist monastic institutions.

Extra Information:

  • The Shailendra dynasty played a crucial role in the spread and flourishing of Mahayana Buddhism in maritime Southeast Asia.
  • Inscriptions from the period mention Buddhist deities and concepts, further confirming their religious affiliation.
  • The dynasty’s legacy includes not only Borobudur but also other Buddhist monuments and endowments to Buddhist institutions, including those as far away as Nalanda in India.

question:
________ was the first woman to be ordained as a bhikkuni in Buddhism.

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
Mahapajapati Gotami was the firstwoman to be ordainedas a bhikkhuni (Buddhistnun) in Buddhism.Shewas the foster-mother, step-mother, and maternalaunt of Gautama Buddha, havingraised him afterthe death ofhis birth mother, Queen Maya. Accordingto Buddhist tradition, Mahapajapati Gotami was the firstwoman to requestordination forwomen directlyfrom the Buddha.

Although initiallyrefused, shepersisted and, with the supportof Ananda (one ofBuddha’s chiefdisciples), herrequest was eventuallygranted on thecondition thatshe accept theEight Garudhammas (strictrules for nuns). Byaccepting these, she became thefirst bhikkhuni, thusfounding theorder of nuns (bhikkhuniSangha) in Buddhism.

Her ordination wasa historic milestone, paving the wayfor women’s monasticism and spiritualequality in theBuddhist community. Mahapajapati Gotami’s determinationand devotionare celebratedin Buddhist texts, and her storyis widely recordedacross variousBuddhist traditions.

Extra Information:

  • Mahapajapati Gotami’s ordination inspired500 other womento join the monastic order atthe same time.
  • She is reveredfor her compassionand leadership, and her lifeis detailed inthe Pali Canonand other Buddhistscriptures.
  • Otheroptions suchas Dhammananda Bhikkhuni, Sujata, andSanghamitta wereimportant womenin Buddhist history, but Mahapajapati Gotami holds thedistinction ofbeing the veryfirst ordainedbhikkhuni.

question:
Which Kushana ruler was famous in history as a great patron of Buddhism and organized the fourth Buddhist Council?

SSC MTS 25/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
Kanishka, one of the greatest rulers of the Kushan dynasty, is renowned in history as a major patron of Buddhism. He is especially famous for convening the Fourth Buddhist Council, which took place in Kashmir during his reign in the 2nd century CE.This council is considered a landmark event in Buddhist history, as it marked the formal emergence and codification of Mahayana Buddhism. The council, presided over by the Buddhist scholars Vasumitra and Ashvaghosha, resulted in the compilation and commentary of Buddhist scriptures, which were engraved on copper plates.

Kanishka’s reign was notable for the flourishing of Buddhist art, literature, and architecture. He supported the construction of stupas and monasteries, and his patronage helped Buddhism spread along the Silk Road to Central Asia and China.The Gandhara and Mathura schools of art, which depicted the Buddha in human form, reached new heights under his rule. Although Kanishka himself did not convert to Buddhism, his support and sponsorship were instrumental in the development and international spread of the religion.

Extra Information:

  • Kanishka’s capital was Purushapura (modern-day Peshawar).
  • His reign saw the blending of Greco-Roman and Indian artistic influences, especially in Buddhist iconography.
  • The Fourth Buddhist Council under Kanishka’s patronage is a defining moment in the history of Mahayana Buddhism.

question:
With reference to Buddhist architecture, what does chaitya mean?

SSC MTS 09/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
In Buddhistarchitecture, a "chaitya" refersspecificallyto a prayer hallor a place ofworship. Thesehalls were designedfor congregational worshipand typicallyhoused a stupa (a sacredmound or relicstructure) atone end, usuallywithin an apsidal (rounded) endof the hall. Thearchitecturallayout of a chaitya often includesa long, barrel-vaulted hallwith columnsdividing thecentral navefrom side aisles, allowingdevotees to circumambulate the stupa as part oftheir ritualpractice.

Unlikeviharas, whichserved as residentialmonasteries formonks, chaityas werebuilt for assembly, prayer, andreligious ceremonies. The earliestchaityas weremade of wood, but later exampleswere rock-cut, suchas those at Bhaja, Karla, andAjanta. The term"chaitya" ismost commonlyassociated withBuddhist architecture, but it can alsorefer more generallyto any sacredmonument or shrinein Indian religions.

Extra Information:

  • The word"chaitya" comesfrom the Sanskritroot "chita," meaninga sacred placeor mound.
  • Thestupa insidethe chaitya isthe focal pointfor worship, symbolizing the Buddhaor Buddhist relics.
  • Some of themost famous chaitya halls arefound in therock-cut cavesof Maharashtra, such as Karla and Bhaja.

question:
Which of the following structure is associated with Buddhism?

SSC MTS 10/05/2023
solution:
The structure most closely associated with Buddhism is the stupa. A stupa is a dome-shaped, mound-like monument that contains relics of the Buddha or other revered Buddhist figures and is a central feature of Buddhist architecture and worship.Originating in India before the 5th century BCE, stupas were initially simple burial mounds but evolved into sacred monuments central to Buddhist practice. Emperor Ashoka of the Mauryan dynasty played a major role in popularizing stupas by building thousands across his empire to enshrine the Buddha’s relics and propagate Buddhism.

Stupas serve as important pilgrimage sites and places for meditation, symbolizing the Buddha’s enlightenment and the path to spiritual liberation. Their design is rich in symbolism: the dome (anda) represents the universe, the central pillar (yasti) symbolizes the axis mundi (cosmic axis), and the parasols (chhatras) atop the stupa signify the Buddha’s teachings and protection.The stupa’s gateways (toranas) are often adorned with carvings depicting events from the Buddha’s life and Jataka tales.

Other structures listed—such as Mandapa and Shikhara—are primarily associated with Hindu temple architecture, and "Pallava" refers to a South Indian dynasty, not a structure.

Extra Information:

  • Stupas are found throughout Asia, including famous examples like the Great Stupa at Sanchi (India), Borobudur (Indonesia), and Shwedagon Pagoda (Myanmar).
  • The practice of circumambulating (walking around) the stupa is an important Buddhist ritual.
  • The stupa’s form has influenced the development of other Buddhist architectural forms such as pagodas in East Asia.

question:
The rules made for the Buddhist “Sangha” were written down in a book called__________ .

SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
The rules made for the Buddhist “Sangha” (the monastic community of monks and nuns) were written down in a book called the Vinaya Pitaka. The Vinaya Pitaka is one of the three main sections of the Pali Canon (Tipitaka) and serves as the foundational text for monastic discipline in Buddhism. It contains detailed rules and codes of conduct for bhikkhus (monks) and bhikkhunis (nuns), outlining proper behavior, ethical guidelines, and procedures for resolving disputes and maintaining harmony within the Sangha.

The Vinaya Pitaka was compiled to ensure discipline and ethical behavior among members of the monastic community. It includes not only the rules themselves but also stories about how and why these rules were established by the Buddha, often in response to specific incidents. The text is divided into several sections, including the Suttavibhanga (rules for monks and nuns), Khandhaka (additional regulations and rituals), and Parivara (summary and commentary on the rules).The Vinaya Pitaka remains the authoritative source for monastic regulations in Theravada Buddhism and has influenced the development of monastic codes in other Buddhist traditions as well.

Extra Information:

  • The Vinaya Pitaka emphasizes the importance of discipline (Vinaya) as inseparable from the teachings (Dhamma) of the Buddha.
  • It provides valuable insights into the daily life, organization, and ethical standards of the early Buddhist community.
  • The other options listed—Abhidhamma Pitaka, Sutta Pitaka, and Milinda Panha—do not focus on monastic rules: Abhidhamma Pitaka deals with Buddhist philosophy, Sutta Pitaka with the Buddha’s discourses, and Milinda Panha is a later text of philosophical dialogues.

question:
In Buddhist architecture, which among the following are meditation cells and living quarters for the monks?

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Morning)
solution:
In Buddhist architecture, "viharas" are meditation cells and living quarters for monks. Originally, viharas referred to simple shelters for monks during the rainy season, but over time, they evolved into more complex monastic residences. Architecturally, a typical vihara consists of a central hall surrounded by small individual cells, which served as meditation spaces and sleeping quarters for monks.These cells often had stone beds carved from the rock, and the central hall was used for communal activities or study.Viharas were crucial centers for meditation, scriptural study, teaching, and community gatherings, playing a central role in the spiritual and intellectual life of Buddhist monastic communities.

Some of the most famous examples of viharas are found in the rock-cut cave complexes of Ajanta, Ellora, Kanheri, and Karla in India.Over time, large monastic complexes known as "mahaviharas" developed, such as Nalanda and Vikramashila, which could accommodate thousands of monks and became renowned centers of Buddhist learning.

Other options:

  • Chaitya Grihas are prayer or assembly halls, not living quarters.
  • Pietra dura is an inlay technique, not a Buddhist architectural structure.
  • Stupas are dome-shaped structures for housing relics, not residences.

Extra Information:

  • Viharas were often built near trade routes for easy access to resources and donations.
  • The design of viharas influenced the development of monastic architecture throughout Asia.
  • Viharas remain central to Buddhist monastic life, providing space for meditation, study, and communal living.

question:
The Buddha belonged to a small gana known as _________ .

SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Morning)
solution:
The Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama, belonged to a small gana (republic or oligarchic clan) known as the Sakya gana. The Sakyas were a Kshatriya clan who lived in the foothills of the Himalayas, in what is now southern Nepal and northern India.The Sakya gana was organized as a republic, or "ganasangha," governed by an assembly of elders rather than a monarchy. Siddhartha's father, Suddhodana, was the elected chief of this republic.

This political structure was distinct from the larger monarchical kingdoms (Mahajanapadas) of ancient India. The Buddha’s background in a small republican state influenced the egalitarian and communal aspects of the early Buddhist Sangha (monastic community).The Sakyas are so closely associated with the Buddha that he was often called "Shakyamuni," meaning "Sage of the Sakyas".

Other options—Avanti, Kuru, and Panchal—were separate and larger political entities during that period and not associated with the Buddha’s life.

Extra Information:

  • The Sakya republic was eventually annexed by the Kingdom of Kosala during the Buddha’s lifetime.
  • The Buddha was born in Lumbini, near Kapilavastu, the capital of the Sakya gana.
  • The republican structure of the Sakyas is reflected in the organization of the early Buddhist community.

question:
Sanchi stupta is located in which states?

SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
The Sanchi Stupa is located in the state of Madhya Pradesh, India. Specifically, it is situated on a hilltop in Sanchi Town, Raisen District, about 46 kilometers northeast of Bhopal, the capital of Madhya Pradesh.

The Great Stupa at Sanchi is one of the oldest stone structures in India and was originally commissioned by Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE. Sanchi is globally renowned for its Buddhist stupas, temples, monasteries, and the iconic Ashoka Pillar. The Sanchi Stupa is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a major center for Buddhist pilgrimage and heritage tourism.

Extra Information:

  • The Sanchi complex includes several stupas, temples, and monasteries, with the Great Stupa being the most prominent.
  • The site flourished as a center of Buddhist art and architecture from the 3rd century BCE to the 12th century CE.
  • The Sanchi Stupa is admired for its elaborate gateways (toranas) and detailed carvings depicting scenes from the life of the Buddha.

question:
Buddha meditated for days on end under a peepal tree at _______ where he attained enlightenment.

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
Buddha meditated for days on end under a peepal tree, known as the Bodhi Tree, at Bodh Gaya, where he attained enlightenment (Bodhi). This sacred fig tree (Ficus religiosa) is located in Bodh Gaya, Bihar, India, and is one of the most important pilgrimage sites for Buddhists worldwide. According to Buddhist tradition, Siddhartha Gautama sat in deep meditation under this tree for 49 days, resisting various temptations and distractions, until he achieved supreme enlightenment and became the Buddha.

The original Bodhi Tree under which the Buddha meditated no longer exists, but the current tree at the Mahabodhi Temple complex is believed to be a direct descendant of the original. Emperor Ashoka, a great patron of Buddhism, built the first temple at this site around 250 BCE to commemorate the Buddha’s enlightenment. The Bodhi Tree and the Mahabodhi Temple remain central to Buddhist worship and pilgrimage.

Extra Information:

  • The Bodhi Tree is also called the Bo Tree and is recognizable by its heart-shaped leaves.
  • Bodh Gaya is considered one of the four main Buddhist pilgrimage sites.
  • The site symbolizes the moment of the Buddha’s awakening and the beginning of his teaching mission.

question:
What was the pedestrian path for devotees to wave in homage to Stupta called in Buddhist architecture?

SSC MTS 05/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
In Buddhist architecture, the pedestrian path specifically designed for devotees to walk around the stupa in homage is called the "Medhi".The Medhi is a raised circular platform encircling the main dome (anda) of the stupa, and it serves as the pradakshina patha, or circumambulatory path, for ritual worship.

Circumambulation (walking clockwise around the stupa) is a key devotional practice in Buddhism, symbolizing reverence for the Buddha and his teachings. The Medhi allows devotees to perform this ritual, keeping the stupa to their right as they walk, which is considered auspicious and meritorious.

Other architectural elements of the stupa include:

  • Torana:Ornamental gateway at the entrance to the stupa complex.
  • Anda:The hemispherical dome representing the main body of the stupa.
  • Chattra:The umbrella-like structure at the top, symbolizing protection and royalty.

The Medhi is thus the designated path for devotees to pay homage to the stupa, and is an essential feature of Buddhist stupa architecture.

question:
Which of the following is the largest stupa in India?

SSC MTS 07/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
The largest stupa in India is the Kesariya Stupa, located in Kesariya, East Champaran district, Bihar. The stupa stands at a height of about 104 feet (32 meters) and has a circumference of nearly 400 feet (approximately 1,400 feet according to some sources), making it not only the largest in India but also considered the tallest and largest Buddhist stupa in the world.

Historically, the Kesariya Stupa dates back to the 3rd century BCE, with its original construction attributed to the Mauryan emperor Ashoka. The current structure mainly dates to the Gupta period (between 200 and 750 CE), but archaeological evidence suggests its foundation is much older, possibly linked to the Licchavis of Vaishali before Buddha's Nirvana.The stupa was once taller—up to 123 feet before the 1934 Bihar earthquake, and historical records state it may have reached 150 feet during the peak of Buddhism in India.Even today, it is taller than the famous Sanchi Stupa (77.5 feet) and the Borobudur Stupa in Indonesia (currently 103 feet).

Kesariya Stupa is an important pilgrimage site for Buddhists and is recognized for its architectural grandeur and historical significance. The site features multiple terraces, a pradakshina path (circumambulatory path), and numerous Buddha images, making it a remarkable monument of Buddhist heritage.

Extra Information:

  • The stupa is located about 110 km from Patna, Bihar.
  • It was rediscovered and excavated by the Archaeological Survey of India in 1998.
  • The site is associated with significant events from Buddha’s life, including his last journey and his giving of the begging bowl to the Licchavis.

question:
Question: Ramabhar Stupa, which marks the site where Lord Buddha was cremated, is situated in which state of India?

SSC MTS 07/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
Ramabhar Stupa, which marks the site where Lord Buddha was cremated, is situated in Kushinagar district, Uttar Pradesh, India.This stupa is also known as Mukutbandhan Chaitya and is one of the most significant Buddhist pilgrimage sites in the world. According to Buddhist tradition and archaeological evidence, the stupa was built over a portion of Buddha’s ashes at the very spot where his cremation was performed by the ancient Malla people after he attained Mahaparinirvana (final liberation) in 483 BCE.

Kushinagar is a major center for Buddhist pilgrimage as it is believed to be the place where Gautama Buddha passed away and was cremated.The stupa stands near a pond called Ramabhar and is located about 1.5 to 2 kilometers from the Parinirvana Temple in Kushinagar.The structure, made of bricks, rises to about 15 meters (49 feet) in height and has a circular plan with a diameter of about 34 meters.

Extra Information:

  • The Ramabhar Stupa is surrounded by meditation parks and monasteries, contributing to its spiritual atmosphere.
  • It is a protected monument and attracts pilgrims, monks, and tourists from around the world.
  • Kushinagar is accessible by road, rail, and air, with the nearest airport being in Kushinagar itself.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a part of Buddhist stupas?

SSC MTS 11/07/2022 (Afternoon)

The Lion Capital was built to commemorate the historical event of _________ of Buddha.

SSC MTS 13/07/2022 (Morning)
solution:
The Lion Capital was built to commemorate the historical event of Buddha’s first sermon, also known as the "Dhammachakrapravartana" or "Turning of the Wheel of Dharma." This iconic sculpture was erected by Emperor Ashoka around 250 BCE at Sarnath, the very site where Gautama Buddha delivered his first sermon to his five disciples after attaining enlightenment.The first sermon at Sarnath marked the beginning of the Buddha’s public teaching and the foundation of the Buddhist Sangha (monastic community), where he introduced the Four Noble Truths and the Noble Eightfold Path.

The Lion Capital consists of four Asiatic lions seated back-to-back on a drum-shaped abacus, which is adorned with reliefs of wheels (dharmachakras) and animals representing the four cardinal directions. The capital originally supported a large stone wheel (now missing) and was placed atop a monolithic pillar. The Lion Capital is not only a masterpiece of Mauryan art but also a powerful symbol of the spread of Buddhism and the Buddha’s teachings. It was adopted as the National Emblem of India after independence.

Extra Information:

  • The Lion Capital is displayed at the Sarnath Museum, near its original site.
  • The abacus features a bull, horse, elephant, and lion, symbolizing strength, speed, wisdom, and courage.
  • The event commemorated by the Lion Capital—Buddha’s first sermon—is considered a turning point in world religious history, as it marked the formal beginning of Buddhism as a religious movement.

question:
Bharhut Stupa depict the jataka tales and stories. It is located in which of the following states?

SSC MTS 14/07/2022 (Afternoon)
solution:
Bharhut Stupa is located in the village of Bharhut in the Satna district of Madhya Pradesh, central India.This ancient Buddhist stupa is renowned for its intricately carved railings and gateways, which vividly depict the Jataka tales—stories of the previous lives of the Buddha—as well as other important events from Buddhist lore.The stupa was originally constructed during the Mauryan period, likely under Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE, and was later expanded and embellished by the Sunga dynasty in the 2nd century BCE.

The Bharhut Stupa is a significant example of early Buddhist art and architecture. Its panels are unique because many are explicitly labeled in Brahmi script, identifying the scenes they portray.While much of the original stupa is now in ruins, many sculptures and railings from Bharhut have been preserved in the Indian Museum in Kolkata and other institutions.The site is an important destination for those interested in Buddhist history and the development of narrative art in ancient India.

Extra Information:

  • Bharhut is about 14–21 kilometers from Satna town and is accessible by road and rail.
  • The stupa’s reliefs are considered among the earliest and most detailed surviving examples of Buddhist narrative art in India.
  • The site was rediscovered by British archaeologist Alexander Cunningham in 1873.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

I. Gautama Buddha belonged to a small gana known as the Sakya gana and was a Kshatriya.

II. Gautama Buddha passed away at Kusinara.

SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Morning)
option_2: Neither I nor II
option_4: Both I and II
solution:
Statement I: Gautama Buddha belonged to a small gana known as the Sakya gana and was a Kshatriya.

This statement is correct. Gautama Buddha, originally named Siddhartha, was born into the Sakya clan (gana), a small republican community in the Himalayan foothills. The Sakyas were Kshatriyas (the warrior and ruling class in ancient Indian society), and Buddha’s father, Suddhodana, was the elected chief of this clan.

Statement II: Gautama Buddha passed away at Kusinara.

This statement is also correct. Historical and archaeological evidence confirms that Gautama Buddha attained Mahaparinirvana (final liberation) at Kushinagar (ancient Kusinara), in present-day Uttar Pradesh, India.After his death, his body was cremated at the Ramabhar Stupa in Kushinagar, and the site is now one of the most important Buddhist pilgrimage centers.

Extra Information:

  • The Sakya gana was organized as a republic, not a monarchy, and their capital was Kapilavastu.
  • Kushinagar is recognized as one of the four main pilgrimage sites in Buddhism, along with Lumbini, Bodh Gaya, and Sarnath.
  • The Parinirvana Stupa and Ramabhar Stupa in Kushinagar commemorate the Buddha’s passing and cremation, respectively.

question:
‘Chethiyagiri Vihara’ is a ________ festival celebrated in Sanchi.

SSC MTS 14/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
Chethiyagiri Vihara is a Buddhist festival celebrated annually in Sanchi, located in the Raisen district of Madhya Pradesh, India. The festival takes place every November and is a major event for Buddhist pilgrims from across India and abroad. The main highlight of the Chethiyagiri Vihara festival is the public display and veneration of the sacred relics of Sariputta and Mahamoggallana, who were the two chief disciples of Gautama Buddha. These relics were discovered in Stupa 3 at Sanchi and are usually kept enshrined within the vihara (monastic complex).

During the festival, the relics are brought out for public viewing, and thousands of devotees gather to pay homage. The event not only has deep religious significance for Buddhists but also draws attention to Sanchi’s historical importance as a center of Buddhist art, culture, and pilgrimage. Sanchi is renowned for its ancient stupas, especially the Great Stupa commissioned by Emperor Ashoka in the 3rd century BCE, and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Extra Information:

  • The Chethiyagiri Vihara festival strengthens Sanchi’s status as a major Buddhist pilgrimage destination.
  • The relics of Sariputta and Mahamoggallana were rediscovered in the 19th century and are central to the festival’s rituals.
  • The festival is attended by monks, pilgrims, and tourists from India and many Buddhist countries, especially Sri Lanka.
  • Sanchi’s Buddhist monuments are among the oldest and most well-preserved in India, reflecting the region’s rich Buddhist heritage.

question:
The earliest Buddhist texts were written in:

SSC MTS 22/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
The earliest Buddhist texts were written in the Pali language. The Pali Canon, also known as the Tipitaka or Tripitaka, is the most complete and earliest collection of Buddhist scriptures and forms the foundation of the Theravada Buddhist tradition.These texts include the Vinaya Pitaka (rules for monastic discipline), the Sutta Pitaka (Buddha's discourses), and the Abhidhamma Pitaka (philosophical and doctrinal analysis).

Initially, the teachings of the Buddha were passed down orally for several centuries after his death. It was only around the 1st century BCE, in Sri Lanka, that the Pali Canon was first committed to writing to preserve the teachings during times of crisis such as famine and war.The use of Pali, a Middle Indo-Aryan language, made the teachings accessible to a broad audience in ancient India.While the Buddha likely taught in several regional dialects, Pali became the standard literary and liturgical language for early Buddhist scriptures.

Other languages, such as Sanskrit, Prakrit, and Apabhramsha, were used for later Buddhist texts or in other Buddhist traditions, but Pali is recognized as the language of the earliest Buddhist writings.

Extra Information:

  • The Pali Canon remains the authoritative scripture for Theravada Buddhists and is still studied and recited today.
  • Important Pali texts include the Tripitaka, Deep Vansha, Maha Vansha, and Milind Pannaho.
  • Non-Pali (Anupali) Buddhist texts, such as the Divyavadana and Lalitavistara, were composed in Sanskrit and other languages at a later date.

question:
Which of the following Buddhist sites is located in Uttar Pradesh?

SSC CGL 13/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
Sarnath is a renowned Buddhist site located in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India, just northeast of Varanasi. It holds immense historical and spiritual significance as the place where Gautama Buddha delivered his first sermon after attaining enlightenment, an event known as the "Turning of the Wheel of Dharma" (Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta).This sermon marked the foundation of the Buddhist Sangha (monastic community) and the beginning of the spread of Buddhist teachings.

Sarnath is home to several important monuments, including the Dhamek Stupa, which marks the exact spot of the first sermon, the Ashoka Pillar with its famous Lion Capital (now the national emblem of India), and the remains of ancient monasteries and temples.Emperor Ashoka, a key patron of Buddhism, built many of these structures in the 3rd century BCE to commemorate the Buddha’s teachings.

Today, Sarnath is one of the four most important Buddhist pilgrimage sites in the world, alongside Lumbini, Bodh Gaya, and Kushinagar. It attracts pilgrims, scholars, and tourists from across the globe, and its archaeological treasures are preserved in the Sarnath Archaeological Museum.

Extra Information:

  • Sarnath is about 8 kilometers from Varanasi and is easily accessible by road.
  • The site features the Chaukhandi Stupa, Dhamek Stupa, Ashoka Pillar, and several ancient monasteries.
  • The Lion Capital of Ashoka, found at Sarnath, is the official emblem of India.

question:
The rules made for the _________ were written down in a book called ‘Vinaya Pitaka’.

SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
The rules made for the Buddhist sangha (the monastic community of monks and nuns) were written down in a book called the Vinaya Pitaka. The Vinaya Pitaka is one of the three main sections of the Pali Canon (Tipitaka) and forms the textual and ethical framework for Buddhist monastic life.It contains detailed rules and codes of conduct that regulate the daily life, discipline, and behavior of monks (bhikkhus) and nuns (bhikkhunis) within the sangha.These rules were established by the Buddha himself to ensure harmonious living, ethical behavior, and proper functioning of the monastic community.

The Vinaya Pitaka not only outlines specific disciplinary rules but also provides procedures for ordination, resolving disputes, handling misconduct, and maintaining order within the sangha.Its importance lies in preserving the discipline and unity of the monastic community, which is considered essential for the continued transmission of the Buddha's teachings.Other parts of the Pali Canon, such as the Sutta Pitaka and Abhidhamma Pitaka, focus on the Buddha’s teachings and philosophy, while the Vinaya Pitaka is dedicated specifically to monastic discipline.

Extra Information:

  • The Vinaya Pitaka is divided into three main sections: Suttavibhanga (rules for monks and nuns), Khandhaka (additional regulations and rituals), and Parivara (summary and commentary on the rules).
  • The rules cover a wide range of topics, from daily conduct and etiquette to procedures for ordination and penalties for transgressions.
  • The Vinaya Pitaka remains the foundation for monastic life in Theravada Buddhism and has influenced other Buddhist traditions as well.

question:
At which of the following places did Lord Buddha give his first sermon on the Four Noble Truths?

SSC CGL 20/08/2021 (Morning)
solution:
Lord Buddha gave his first sermon on the Four Noble Truths at Sarnath, near Varanasi in present-day Uttar Pradesh, India. This event is known as the "Dharmachakra Pravartana" or "Turning of the Wheel of Dharma." After attaining enlightenment at Bodh Gaya, Buddha traveled to Sarnath, where he delivered his first discourse to his five former companions in the Deer Park (Mrigadava). This sermon laid the foundation for the Buddhist Sangha (monastic community) and introduced the core principles of Buddhism, including the Four Noble Truths and the Noble Eightfold Path.

The Dhamek Stupa at Sarnath marks the exact spot where this sermon was delivered, and Sarnath is now one of the most important Buddhist pilgrimage sites in the world. The choice of Sarnath was significant because it symbolized peace and the beginning of Buddha’s mission to spread his teachings. The event is commemorated in Buddhist art and literature as a pivotal moment in the history of Buddhism.

Extra Information:

  • Sarnath is located about 8 kilometers from Varanasi and is easily accessible.
  • The Lion Capital of Ashoka, found at Sarnath, is now the national emblem of India.
  • Sarnath is one of the four major pilgrimage sites for Buddhists, along with Lumbini, Bodh Gaya, and Kushinagar.

question:
The ‘Gandhara’ School of Art was influenced by the art from which of the following European countries?

SSC CPO 23/11/2020 (Morning)
solution:
The Gandhara School of Art was heavily influenced by the art and culture of ancient Greece. This influence is evident in the realistic depiction of human figures, drapery, and facial expressions found in Gandhara sculptures. The style emerged as a result of the interaction between Greek culture—introduced to the Indian subcontinent after Alexander the Great’s incursions—and the indigenous Buddhist culture of the Gandhara region (present-day Pakistan and Afghanistan).

Gandhara art is often described as Greco-Buddhist art because it represents a fusion of Greek (Hellenistic) artistic traditions with Buddhist themes. This is visible in features such as wavy hair, deeply carved drapery, and the naturalistic portrayal of the Buddha, reminiscent of Greek gods like Apollo.The Gandhara School reached its zenith under the Kushan Empire (1st–3rd centuries CE), when the first anthropomorphic (human-form) images of the Buddha were created, ending the earlier tradition of representing the Buddha only through symbols.

While Gandhara art also absorbed some Roman artistic elements, the primary and most defining foreign influence was Greek. The motifs, techniques, and iconography of Gandhara sculptures clearly reflect Hellenistic ideals, making Greece the European country most associated with the development of this unique art style.

Extra Information:

  • The main centers of Gandhara art were Taxila, Peshawar, Begram, and Bamiyan.
  • Gandhara art played a major role in spreading Buddhist iconography across Central and East Asia.
  • The Lion Capital, realistic Buddha statues, and elaborate reliefs are hallmarks of this Greco-Buddhist artistic tradition.

question:
Match the following Buddhist councils with their places:

A.First CouncilVaishali

B. Second2. Kashmir

C. Third3. Rajgir

D. Fourth4. Pataliputra
option_1: A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2
option_2: A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
option_3: A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
option_4: A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
solution:
The Correct Answer is: a) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

1st Council – Rajgir

  • Patron: Ajatashatru
  • Presided by: Mahakashyapa
  • Important: Compilation of Vinaya Pitaka & Sutta Pitaka

2nd Council – Vaishali

  • Patron: Kalashoka
  • Important: Addressed monastic discipline disputes, led to first Buddhist sect split into Sthaviravadins and Mahasanghikas

3rd Council – Pataliputra

  • Patron: Ashoka
  • Presided by: Moggaliputta Tissa
  • Important: Compilation of Abhidhamma Pitaka, spread of Buddhism to Sri Lanka & abroad

4th Council – Kashmir

  • Patron: Kanishka (Kushan dynasty)
  • Presided by: Vasumitra (with Ashvaghosha)
  • Important: Compilation of Mahayanist doctrines, division into Hinayana & Mahayana
